Title.evidence: Effect of Obesity on Outcomes of Lumbar Disc Herniation Treatment: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were divided into nonobese (BMI <30 kg/m², n = 854) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m², n = 336) groups.

Participants.evidence: patients enrolled in the Spine Patient Outcomes Research Trial

Intervention.evidence: Participants were divided into nonobese (BMI <30 kg/m², n = 854) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m², n = 336) groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine the impact of obesity on outcomes following treatment for symptomatic lumbar disc herniation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measures included Short Form-36 physical function and bodily pain scores, and the Oswestry Disability Index, assessed at baseline and up to four years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were divided into nonobese (BMI <30 kg/m², n = 854) and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m², n = 336) groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At four years, obese patients showed less improvement in primary outcomes compared to nonobese patients in both operative and nonoperative groups.
